Submodules¶

pyproct.algorithms.kmedoids.kMedoidsAlgorithm module¶

Created on 29/05/2012

@author: victor

class pyproct.algorithms.kmedoids.kMedoidsAlgorithm.KMedoidsAlgorithm(condensed_matrix, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

K-Means like algorithm with medoids (so that the cluster prototype is always a member of the dataset). It has 3 different initial seeding implementations.

MAX_ITERATIONS = 500¶
cluster_update(medoids, condensed_matrix)[source]¶

Assigns each element to a cluster (updating its class), depending on which medoid is closer.

@param medoids: The medoid list. @param condensed_matrix: The dataset’s distance matrix.

convergence(current, last)[source]¶

Checks if the medoid list has changed. If not, then the algorithm has converged.

@param current: The current medoid list in this step. @param last: The medoid list of the previous step.

@return: True if the lists are equal, False otherwise.

equidistant_seeding(k, number_of_elements)[source]¶

@see seeding_types

@param k: The number of medoids we need. @param number_of_elements: Number of elements of the dataset.

@return: The medoid list.

gen_medoid_to_cluster_id_map(medoids)[source]¶

It generates a map defining the relationship between cluster classes and medoids. For instance if k = 3 and our medoid list is [10, 23, 50], class 0 corresponds to medoid 10, so cluster_id_map[10] = class 0

@param medoids: The medoid list.

@return: A medoid to class dictionary.

get_closer_medoid(element, medoids, condensed_matrix)[source]¶

Says which medoid is closer to an element.

@param element: The element of the dataset we want to test. @param condensed_matrix: The dataset’s distance matrix.

@return: The closer medoid to this element.

gromos_seeding(k, seeding_max_cutoff)[source]¶

The first k medoids are selected running the gromos algorithm with an initial cutoff defined in ‘seeding_max_cutoff’ until it gets at least k clusters. If it can’t, it will use the random seeding strategy.

@param k: The number of medoids we need(and thus the number of clusters we want GROMOS to produce) @param seeding_max_cutoff: The initial seeding cutoff to use with the gromos algorithm.

@return: The medoid list.

perform_clustering(kwargs)[source]¶

Does the actual clustering. @param kwargs: Dictionary with this mandatory keys:

  • ‘k’: Number of clusters to generate.

  • ‘seeding_type’: One of the initial medoid selectors available (@see seeding_types() ).

    If seeding type is ‘GROMOS’, ‘seeding_max_cutoff’ must be also defined, containing the cutoff that the GROMOS Algorithm will use.

random_seeding(k)[source]¶

Returns k random medoids.

@param k: The number of medoids we need.

@return: The medoid list.

seeding(k, seeding_max_cutoff, seeding_type)[source]¶

Does the initial seeding using the stated seeding process.

@param k: The number of medoids we need. @param seeding_max_cutoff: The initial seeding cutoff to use with the GROMOS algorithm. @param seeding_type: The seeding process type (@see seeding_types() )

@return: The initial medoids.

seeding_to_str()[source]¶

Convenience function to build the details string.

@return: a string representation of the initial seeding type.

static seeding_types()[source]¶
Returns the possible initial seeding types.

  • GROMOS: Uses GROMOS to get the initial medoids. Useful if clusters are well separated.

  • EQUIDISTANT: Divides the dataset in k consecutive parts and uses their central element as

    medoid. Useful if we suspect that sequence order and geometrical likeness are correlated (for instance with MD sequences).

  • RANDOM: Uses a random choice of elements from the dataset as initial medoids.

update_medoids()[source]¶

Regenerates the medoids list once the new clusters have been generated.

@return: A new medoid list.

pyproct.algorithms.kmedoids.parametersGeneration module¶

Created on 27/05/2013

@author: victor

class pyproct.algorithms.kmedoids.parametersGeneration.ParametersGenerator(parameters, matrix_handler)[source]¶

Bases: object

MAX_CLUSTERING_PARAMETERS = 15.0¶
classmethod get_base_parameters()[source]¶

Defines the base parameters needed for each of the algorithms. Each parameter created will be based on one of those and must not have more keys than these.

@return: A dictionary with the base parameters for this algorithm.

get_parameters()[source]¶

This function creates some parameters to be used with K-Medoids. @return: A tuple with the generated parameters and an empty list corresponding to the clusterings.
